title: Before 1 January 2018, will the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration grant a waiver allowing Amazon to test its unmanned aerial vehicles?
preds: UAVs are the future of civilian aerospace

The US government is technologically clueless, therefore a slave to special interests. The advice they take regarding cyberpolicy is all coming from the tech giants who do, and will continue to rule a corporate owned internet. Cluelessness at the highest level was demonstrated by Jeff Sessions at Senate Committee hearings, proving that, arguably, the White House's top "performer" knows nothing. That means our whole government is putting our security, therefore our national security in the hands of these tech giants. From an old hacker's perspective, my own, I'd interpret Russia's actions, including all election tampering, as an exercise and a dare. It is a dare to see if the Americans are still taking the world seriously. And, the Russians encourage hacking rather than prosecuting people for dissent just for speaking about it. And hacking is a very broad field, a science of reverse engineering. In Russia, they know the difference between hacking and social engineering. It is absolutely vital for all Americans to understand this difference moving forward.

Then, “By 2.00pm ET, January 4, 2018: Lead applicants complete volumes III, IV, V and VI, in the application portal” (https://www.faa.gov/uas/programs_partnerships/uas_integration_pilot_program/) 
Which suggests a waiver will not be granted between now and 1 January 2018.
Waivers will be granted but not yet this year with holidays upon us.

The FAA is requesting “Emergency Clearance to Revise Information Collection 2120-0768, Part 107 Authorisations and Waivers” 
“The FAA is seeking to implement the Low Altitude Authorisation and Notification Capability (LAANC) system.”
“FAA is requesting OMB approval of this collection of information 7 days after publication of this Notice in the Federal Register. Upon OMB approval of its Emergency clearance request, FAA will follow the normal clearance procedures for the information collection associated with LAANC” 
(https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/10/11/2017-21878/request-for-emergency-processing-of-collection-of-information-by-the-office-of-management-and-budget) 
The LAANC will improve the safety of drones flying in controlled airspace, however I don’t think that this implementation will have an impact on Amazon’s UAV testing by the end of the year. Reports are that the prototype of this system will be up by the end of the year. https://www.expouav.com/news/latest/perfect-union-us-regulations-trend-toward-coexistence-uavs-aircraft/

Amazon has continued applying for drone delivery patents, but there seems to be no news on applying to test drones in the US. This possibly indicates that the testing outside the US that Amazon has been doing has reached a point where the technical issues of picking up a package and flying to a deliver address has been achieved but the issues of how to regulate drone deliveries (allocation of air space, privacy, public nuisance etc.) have not, therefore they have nothing new to test.

Based on general news and GJP consensus.

The government is understandably nervous about regulating drone delivery services. On May 31st at a Drone Conference, Elaine Chow (Secretary of Transportation) preached the need for Sillicon Valley firms to share with the public their understanding of their own products, as well as the safety and privacy concerns regarding drones. She also spoke about how the FAA is currently undertaking studies in order to determine the parameters for safe drone flight over people, and admitted that it has been a labor intensive and occasionally frustrating process. Couple this concern over safety/privacy, the fact that the regulation is still squarely in the "research and study" phase, and the relative paralysis of the entire government due to so much political capital being wrapped up in healthcare and the growing Russia scandal, I give a 20% likelihood that Amazon will receive a waiver before January 1st 2018. The only reason I give them such a chance is because of their lobbying power and the single minded will of Jeff Bezos to quickly and decisively move into new areas of opportunity for Amazon.

FAA Safety requirements for UAV waiver: https://www.faa.gov/uas/request_waiver/waiver_safety_explanation_guidelines/
I'm not sure whether Amazon will meet the safety requirements, as this depends on how much testing they've done at their facilities. 
Rules such as: §107.35: Operation of multiple small unmanned aircraft systems, requires the applicant to "Provide a method to resolve failure of single and multiple aircraft or systems simultaneously." 
At their test site in Cambridge, UK, only one drone was operated autonomously, it is possible that they've tested multiple drones simultaneously at their private sites. 
Legislation passed by a House Panel approved Rep. Bill Shuster's legislation that would set rules for drone delivery, beyond -line-of-sight operations, and agreeing on a unified air traffic management system. 
The bill calls for: 
• "The secretary of transportation to decide within 120 days whether or not air traffic management systems are a viable choice for the problem at hand."
• "The FAA to allow flights farther than the pilot can see within six months at six testing regions nationwide."
Lowering as time passes and no visible progress.

There are reasons why the US might be behind with testing delivery drones:-
Property owners rights over their land
A wish to protect delivery drivers jobs
For Amazon Trump might have personal reasons for not helping to change the regulations

Property rights in the US are more citizen friendly than the countries currently allowing drone delivery testing by Amazon.  In 1946, Causby vs. US ruled a specific number of at least 365 feet above the property owner's domain belongs to the property owner.  Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon, is also considered a California liberal and the current Presidential administration has shown a penchant for spiteful behavior towards any opposition.  The FAA is managed by the executive branch of the US government and President Trump is the boss. I predict this issue will drag out for another year or two.

We could use Matternet as a possible marker as to when Amazon would get a waiver. The premise of both Amazon and Matternet’s operations are similar in terms of automated flights being conducted BVLOS:
With the current administration the likelihood is high unless Trump is insulted by something done by Amazon or the Wash Post and orders the FAA to deny permission.

The "line of sight" requirement is reasonable, so FAA would not grant a waiver. Amazon could do its tests anywhere else in the world too, as they did in the UK. It is more likely that Amazon will roll out unmanned delivery service in the UK before doing it in the US, so we would wait for that news first. Also, drone delivery would not be the only way, nor the most efficient way. Aerial delivery would be useful in remote areas or rugged terrains, and visual line of sight is not hard to meet in those cases. Drone delivery in urban area would have to compete with autonomous truck/car/robot, since ground transportation is inherently more economical.

From websites listed below and just googling to read others, it seems like Amazon already received a waiver to test their UAV in the US.  If not, they've certainly flown UAVs as tests and are probably getting a waiver before 2018.

This might hamper Amazon's possibility of getting a waiver before a UAS traffic management system is in place: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/23/us/politics/drone-surveillance-policy.html?module=WatchingPortal&region=c-column-middle-span-region&pgType=Homepage&action=click&mediaId=thumb_square&state=standard&contentPlacement=12&version=internal&contentCollection=www.nytimes.com&contentId=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2017%2F05%2F23%2Fus%2Fpolitics%2Fdrone-surveillance-policy.html&eventName=Watching-article-click&_r=0

Amazon has been pushing delivery drones for years and the public is expecting them. The FAA is open to this new technology for commercial purposes and under the new administration has pressure to make decisions in the best interest of commerce and economic gain. Amazon is becoming a company that continually innovates. I believe they will find a way around the bureaucracy of the FAA.  The FAA hasn't been friendly do drones but Amazon will find a way at least in some markets to use drones.  Class B airspace may be exempt from the waiver until it's a proven technology, meaning they may not get to use the technology in the biggest markets, but medium size markets like Nashville might be available for testing.
It's complicated, and the current administration is more on the side of manual labor and less on advances in technology.

The FAA is under funded, under staffed and seemingly in turmoil. The current administration's desire to privatize air traffic control is at odds with the airlines and the FAA. I think this Amazon request is going to be highly politicized and used for multiple purposes, but the odds of them getting a green light for a rural test similar to what they're doing in the UK are still above average because if the FAA looks like it's thwarting business in the current climate, they'll ultimately be making the case against themselves when fighting those who want to privatize aspects of the agency.
Though they are on the outs with Trump, I doubt this will be important enough to become an issue. I believe they will allow the test.

Lowering forecast as Amazon is increasing its investment in drone delivery research in the UK (where has been testing deliveries). The FAA has been very keen on the idea of maintaining line-of-sight during operations of drones.  Considering Amazon is headquartered in Seattle, it would have difficulty with the FAA granting it access to test their delivery beyond visual sight as Seattle is home to an international airport and various regional airports (I live here).  Additionally, Amazon has fulfillment centers in Illinois, Southern California, Dallas, etc. which are all homes to heavy air traffic.  If Amazon plans on deploying drones to delivery to their main customer base (out of each fulfillment center), it will not get cleared by the FAA to operate in the vicinity of airports.  25% chance as it currently stands.  The FAA is also very underfunded and understaffed.  When Section 333 exemptions were the lay of the land for drone operators, they were backlogged thousands of applications.  They aren't doing a very good job.

The waiver for the test seem to be in the works for late summer. The FAA is still analyzing the results, I have the sense that the FAA will allow at least a few tests. Getting a permit to fly the drones as a de facto service is another story!

Amazon is already testing in the UK, which will give it the great majority of the testing data they need. In addition, they will be able to implement drone deliveries in underdeveloped markets without having to rely on that country's poor shipping/logistics infrastructure. There is not a dying consumer need for drone delivery in the U.S.-- For the most part, U.S. consumers are happy with current Amazon shipping speeds, and in some case can obtain Amazon products at their doorstep within an hour of ordering. Drone deliveries, for the foreseeable future, will be an opportunity to operate in under developed markets and countries.

Most waivers granted by the FAA are single waiver requests versus multiple item waiver requests. To be exact there have been 318 waivers granted for FAR 107. Only 7 waivers have had multiple FAR 107 waiver requests. Only 2.2% of FAR 107 waivers have had multiple FAR 107 line item waivers. The waiver for BNSF Railway is the closest multi-point waiver that could be compared to a Amazon waiver. But we must consider BNSF is not asking to operate over people, at night, and higher weight limits etc etc.  Considering this outside view of 2.2% I should have a much lower forecast for this GJO question right? But I am hung up on the decision makers and politics.

Granting a waiver is problematic for several reasons:  These drones are to be automated, not under the control of or monitored by a person, which is now the law.  The FAA is behind granting waivers to anyone for any reason because of the extremely rapid growth in requests; even search and rescue operations are waiting 90 days.  The technology is advancing so rapidly, any ruling on how to manage automation will already be inadequate in a year.  Plus, it may take a year of study to make a ruling on waivers for automated drones.  The Europeans have already developed and tested automated drone delivery; we know this works, but to do this on a commercial scale is hugely complex and costly.

Although there has been solid movement against drones applications due to security problems that they pose to commercial manned flights we do have out there significant commercial incentives that will push the drone domain and will help find solutions in order to better integrate drone flights with manned flights.
Technical solutions exist- they are already used by the military forces that do operate drones in airspaces "populated" by normal airplanes (human pilot onboard).
Drones were exclusively "military" toys 20 years ago and then "leaked" into the civilian field; similarly we will see technologies used today by the military to integrate drone flight into the airspace leaking towards the civilian applications of drones and helping to integrate their flight within the overall airspace.

The FAA is actually implementing the new medical requirements for GA pilots.  Basically, no more medical evals for GA pilots.  But the rules remain for commercial pilots.  Looking at this GJO question from a different perspective, how will the FAA evaluate the "health"  of commercial UAVs?  Waivers are not granted for commercial pilots if they have certain conditions. Amazon is already testing in the UK, which will give it the great majority of the testing data they need. In addition, they will be able to implement drone deliveries in underdeveloped markets without having to rely on that country's poor shipping/logistics infrastructure. There is not a dying consumer need for drone delivery in the U.S.-- For the most part, U.S. consumers are happy with current Amazon shipping speeds, and in some case can obtain Amazon products at their doorstep within an hour of ordering. Drone deliveries, for the foreseeable future, will be an opportunity to operate in under developed markets and countries.
The FAA will grant a waiver to facilitate innovation in US logistics. The line-of-sight restriction could be replaced by other safety measures.

Most likely yes, since this is not a political but administrative decision, Amazon has a good innovation record, and the question states that it is just about testing, not full-scale implementation. The FAA rules seem to allow it to grant the waiver to Amazon. As the question itself says Amazon is already testing drone deliveries in the UK. So why would it not happen in the US?  I guess Amazon could decide to just stick to the UK for its testing and not bother to get the US waiver, but this seems unlikely.  To move off 100% I would expect to see a good reason why Amazon would not get a waiver.

The FAA have been making changes to airspace and navigation methods over the last several years. The class G airspace is disappearing, and class E and D are becoming more restricted. Densely populated areas are mostly class C or B. Having these drones flying through cities, avoiding controlled airspace will become an ATC nightmare.

There will however be substantial rules and limitations. And there is the privacy issues that will probably be litigated before any of it goes into effect. Not to mention environmental issues impacting the avian and insect populations. It's a dumb idea so I'm certain that Trump will champion it. The only question is how he and his various companies and family members can get in on the profits.
I can imagine this in a low risk, low traffic volume area.  Trump wants to seem pro business.  why can't Amazon maintain line of sight for such an endeavor (helicopter hello)?

A waiver to 'test'? Yes. Permission to operate unmanned drones on an extremely limited basis; i.e., low population areas where it would not be cost effective for Amazon? Yes. Permission to operate extensively country-wide? No.

I think they will apply for waiver, as U.S. their biggest market and they will want to be seen as leaders in the development of drone delivery. As 7-eleven have already got one not sure FAA can refuse one to Amazon if criteria are pretty similar.

Must Amazon get a waiver in order to operate? The FAA reg Part 107 (linked in summary of question) says "Foreign-registered small unmanned aircraft are allowed to operate under part 107 if they satisfy the requirements of part 375." Part 375 seems to be here: http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?node=pt14.4.375#se14.4.375_12

I attach a low probability to this. Under the existing FAA rules Amazon can't test its unmanned drones in the US so it needs a waiver for the rule relating to operator line of sight which the FAA seems unlikely to budge on. They are working with NASA to develop & test a drone traffic monitoring system but this is not due for completion until 2019.  Trump has expressed an interest in privatising air traffic management and replacing the FAA.  The new entity might move quicker on such issues but it would still take some time to set up the new organisation(s) and look at waivers/rule changes. 
additionally, while ultimately drone technology is likely to be used increasingly for commercial purposes, it is still in its infancy.  Amazon will be pressing the FAA and government to act sooner on the issue but I think for the time being they are likely to be quite happy undertaking their testing and refining the technology in the UK and other countries.
It doesn't seem to me that the logistical issues are sufficiently taken care of for the FAA to sign off on this yet.
Trump voters like their on-line purchases to arrive promptly...he'll make sure he's not seen to be the holdup.

Use of unmaned drones out of sight of the pilot pose multiple safety (anti collision) measures, starting from differences in speed as to aircraft, visibility (drones tend to be small), altitude (except near airfields, planes fly above 500 ft, drones could fly below but cannot see other drones) need to be defined first. Maybe ones drones come with built-in anti-collision systems the FAA will give green light, unlikely to happen already in 2017.

Airspace in a populated area is a well regulated entity. The only airspace that is not heavily regulated is very low density population areas. In these areas, aircraft still fly. Additionally all aircraft are governed by rules. Given this, drone regulation would be difficult at best. The areas that drones would serve are also heavily populated. It is therefore an idea that would not be practical or conducive to ground based people and objects or aircraft.
Consistent with new administration's "easing of regulations" thrust. Waiver for testing-only is non-controversial.

It's just a waiver. Could come with all kinds of restrictions and may be extremely limited, such as to specific designated rural areas. Largest problem is the keyword "unmanned", but 7-Eleven got the waiver. https://www.faa.gov/uas/media/Part_107_Summary.pdf

So far the FAA has given lots of waivers but the vast majority are for waiving daylight use. Amazon is looking to waive the line of site requirement. I see few line of site waivers and they replace line of site for the operator with line of site for a visual observer. I am not sure if the FAA is ready to go as far as Amazon would like but the time frame is a year so it must be given some possibility.
Because of amazon project scale and the safety concern from the federal aviation Body, it will take much longer to get the ok on time.

FAA is partnered with NASA to create a "low altitude air traffic control" system for unmanned UAVs.  Publication date for a guideline is 2019.
Meanwhile, UPS, DHL, Amazon and DPD have reportedly moved testing to more regulatory friendly countries.
Unless there is a major disaster of the Hindenburg type, this evolution is inevitable.
I'm a certified pilot and passed the drone test.  Amazon will never get a waiver.
